data.title: Great keyboard
data.body:
With modern day keyboards, I have noticed a lot of keys don't want to go down at weird angles... sadly, not all fingers are shaped perfectly straight and modern day keyboards are terrible for that. This keyboard breaks the mold and is great through and through. The LED is too bright for me, so I disabled it, and the slope at the front of the keyboard is useless to me personally, but the keyboard itself is worth it and more.

You'll never key a key that is crooked and won't go down, the letters and numbers stay on very well, and if you want a specific color to cool... you can do that too. All of the keys are very responsive and I am happy to say it doesn't require any dumb software to get started - unless you want to change the colors a bunch - and even that software is fine.

I purchased two of these now (one for my kid) and even at this point - if anything goes wrong with it, I'd buy another with a smile for how well it has performed through gaming and countless emails - and amazon reviews haha!

data.title: Perfect keystroke feel
data.body:
As an avid gamer, I've always been on the lookout for a keyboard that can keep up with my fast-paced gaming sessions, and this keyboard delivers in every aspect. With its matte black finish and RGB backlighting, it instantly adds a touch of sophistication to my gaming setup. The keys are perfectly spaced and have just the right amount of resistance, making typing and gaming incredibly comfortable.

One of my favorite features of this keyboard is the hybrid mechanical switches. They combine the tactile feedback of a mechanical switch with the soft cushioned feel of a membrane switch. This unique combination provides a satisfying typing experience without compromising on comfort.

Another great feature is the fully programmable macro keys. With these customizable keys, I can assign complex actions or shortcuts to a single key press, giving me a competitive edge in games. It's incredibly convenient and has saved me countless keystrokes.

If I had to nitpick, I would say that the Ornata V3 X could benefit from dedicated media controls. While it does have media function keys integrated into the top row, having dedicated buttons would make adjusting volume or skipping tracks easier during gameplay.

Overall, I am very happy with my new keyboard and don't see myself replacing it anytime soon.

data.title: I can't believe I stalled buying another one of these for so long.
data.body:
I had an old version of this keyboard, a bit of a cheaper model, and I LOVED IT. The feel. The key pressure. The sound. Everything was perfect for my hands and typing speed. I don't even use it for gaming, just writing. Unfortunately, my old one broke on me after a year so I was hesitant to get another one. I got another cheaper-ish keyboard from a different company, and it was horrible. Everything was wrong. The keys were too big. It hurt to type and still I put off investing in a new one of these.
Now that I have one again, I'm sad I waited so long. I actually enjoy typing again and don't get so frustrated with all the mistakes. I'd rather risk replacing this one every year than use whatever the other keyboard I had was. Hopefully that first one was just a fluke. I can't say I always take the best care of my equipment, so it could be on me too.
We'll see.

data.title: It’s good, but not perfect…for the price
data.body:
Pros:

• Nice, sleek design
• Keys feel nice to type on (for membrane keys anyway) as in they have a pleasant feedback and the keys’ surface is pleasantly soft to the touch
• The RGB backlighting can get super bright, which I am not used to. I like the option to change it. I’m not used to that option for a keyboard.
• Worked right away with Windows 10 without Razer software
• The cable routing option underneath the keyboard was an unexpected surprise. Nice touch Razer!

Cons:

• You apparently need the Razer Synapse software to change the RGB lighting, among other things.
• That space bar much louder compared to all the other keys, and you most definitely will notice it. (Very loud for a membrane keyboard anyway.)
• The keys are a bit tough to see without any lighting on, but not too bad. (I am just used to the Logitech K120 keyboard’s highly visible keys.)
• The lack of dedicated media buttons, but I knew that before purchase.
• The Synapse software is fascinating, yet quite slow. It’s still interesting to use, but not a positive in my book for a keyboard. (Try the Synapse Beta software instead, as it seemed more responsive.)

Main review:

I am coming from using a typical, no-frills, cheap keyboard called the Logitech K120 that is quite popular and I have had no issues with. I just wanted to try something…new.

This is my first gaming keyboard I tried since getting a Saitek Eclipse (series 1) with membrane keys back in 2008. I loved that Eclipse keyboard. I never had a gaming keyboard before that, and I just plugged the USB cable into my new desktop PC at the time and it worked. The Saitek Eclipse had dedicated/separate volume buttons and backlighting button on it other than using the function keys or something. The keys felt great and it never let me down for many years before I sold it for some reason. Also, I don’t recall needing to have downloaded some software unlike this Razer one to get the backlighting to work. No it didn’t have RGB lighting, but a keyboard with backlighting was amazing to me for a new desktop PC. Sure, this Razer keyboard works without downloading Razer’s Synapse software, but I wish there was a way to change the backlight color without it. That’s my main gripe about this Razer keyboard. I still haven’t tried the highly touted mechanical keyboards that I have been reading about for eons, but I have loved membrane keyboards so much that I haven’t felt the need to try mechanical yet. I may change my mind soon.

This keyboard evokes a bit of the same feeling as that keyboard, although this Razer keyboard of course doesn’t have dedicate media buttons. Do I need those dedicated media buttons? Not really…but they sure came in handy and I knew where they were and were easily accessible on the keyboard.

So, what I did after trying this Razer keyboard for a couple days is order a full-size Corsair K55 RGB gaming membrane keyboard with dedicated media buttons as well to see which one I respond to better.

Overall, I think you will enjoy this gaming keyboard (for the price) if you have modest expectations and don’t require lots of features on many other more expensive gaming keyboards that I have read about before opting for this one.

data.title: Normal, Basic, keyboard but works with Razer Synapse
data.body:
I know that some people are really picky about keyboards. When I started looking into getting a new one for myself, I saw lots of people talking about things like how raised they buttons are, how much noise they make, layout, etc. Personally even though I use my computer a lot, and I'm always typing, I don't care that much. My only preference is (and it is just a preference for me, not a deal breaker) is I like lower, non-raised keys which makes typing more comfortable and less strenuous on the fingers, though it's worth mentioning since this is a gaming keyboard, I don't think it really makes much difference when gaming.

My other preference, is I like a "full" keyboard layout. I don't care if the overall keyboard is big because it's a wired keyboard, so obviously it's for a stationary setup (if your not moving it around, why does size matter?) Also I like having the numpad, which I use quite a bit.

Anyway, the whole reason I even decided to buy a new keyboard is I have gaming mouse that is also razer and I've really come to appreciate how cool having the ability to rebind and macro commands to different keys. My birthday came up, and I decided to get a cheap razer keyboard just so it would work with Razer Synapse.

Honestly if your a keyboard connoisseur and you want to be able to control the RGB lights and have the keys make just the right amount of clicking sound or whatever, I'm sure you'll find something wrong with the keyboard and not like because it is pretty basic.

If you are like me however and are just looking for a slight upgrade or something that works with Razer Synapse, this is a great keyboard for a reasonable price!

My only complaint is by default the RGB lights are pretty bright, it's kinda jarring at night, even if you are using your computer with a nearby light to keep the room from being dark (which you should be doing if your looking at screen, it's better for your eyes). Also color of the light cycles on its own, which I don't really like. I don't even really care about RGB lights other than just allowing me to see the keys in the dark, so I'd rather they just stay one color. I don't care that much about it to take off a star though, and I've heard there are ways to adjust this either with third party software, or through something provided by Razer.

data.title: Well made keyboard
data.body: Very nice keyboard I like it a lot, you can customize the light pattern and even turn them off in the Razer download. The keys are very nice and responsive nothing sticky or noisy, low profile compact design fits well in smaller spaces. Or if your like me an artist who's desk has to double as art space and gaming space. This keyboard will work for you very well!

data.title: Great
data.body: After about 10 months only the shift key has faded a bit. Other than that works perfectly for daily use.

data.title: Falls apart very quickly
data.body:
I bought the Ornata v3 from Amazon but was sent something else entirely, so I returned it and ended up picking one up from the store. Figured I'd leave a review here to try to warn people about the quality of this thing.

I've been using Ornatas for ages. For whatever reason, I actually prefer the feel of these to the several mechanical keyboards I've tried, and I've been using Razer for so long that the spacing is perfect for me. With both the original Ornata and Ornata v2, the only reason I upgraded was thinking the new one would be better despite loving the one I had.

The v3 is legitimately terrible. I have now had the plastic connectors break off from seven keys in less than 6 months. I have never had this happen with an Ornata before. The n-key rollover is significantly less than past models as well, meaning it won't register more than a few simultaneous key presses. I know this is a budget keyboard, but the Ornatas always have been and I've never had any issue with quality. If you're looking to spend this little on a keyboard, I'd definitely recommend going with something else. Maybe I've just been lucky with Razer products over the past decade, but this is the first quality issue I've seen and a quick search made it clear that this is a very common issue for the v3.

data.title: Keys feel great, similar to v1 of the full size KB of the same name
data.body:
The only DISLIKE I have about this KB is the wrist rest. I don't understand how Razer thinks that people like this stuff. Not only is that wrist rest uncomfortable, the slope and angle of the rest is like rolleyes dumb. I ended up using my wrist/palm rest from my full size v1 Ornata that finally was at end of life and that gives this keyboard an amazing feel while typing and gaming. It also is magnetic and snaps right up to this board when aligned right.

Likes:
Have always liked chiclet or half concave caps like these. Still like the quasi-membrane feel to these keys (listed as mechanical-membrane keys in technicals). RGB is brighter than generations past, so set your color right or be amazed at the color and not at your gameplay. The addition of the media keys at upper right corner was a nice touch.

Suggestions for Razer:
For the love of god, get suggestions from the broader audience first before doing something you think is "nice" but not "practical", especially related to the wrist/palm wrest.

data.title: good quiet light up keyboard
data.body:
This keyboard is pretty good. The only issue I've noticed is that the shift key on the right side tends to stick a bit, which has caused some confusion for me at times since I prefer to use hot keys to do a lot of my actions, so when this first started happening I couldn't figure out why my computer wasn't doing what I was telling it to do.
Other than that, the keyboard has been good. Its quiet and the backlighting is good.
I had thought I could control the backlighting; however, it just cycles through the colors. This has been a pleasant mistake, as the slow transition of colors is actually kind of soothing.
All in all, a good keyboard, and worth the money paid.

data.title: Low-Entry Gaming Keyboard
data.body: Bought this for my son and it ended up on my desk not too long after because he didn't prefer it and wanted a mechanical gaming keyboard instead. I don't have any issues with it as it is mostly a soft-press type keyboard that feels just like any low profile keyboard. To make the lighting scheme stick, you have to create an account on the Razer site which I find to be ridiculous, so I didn't do it. My son did and seemed happy that it kept his preferences. A note to Mac users....the keyboard will work for you, but you do not have any ability to modify the lighting, so it just slowly rotates through all its colors randomly.

data.title: Great Keyboard!
data.body: I love this Keyboard! After my 12-year-old Razer Lycosa Gaming Keyboard stopped working I decided to purchase the Razer Ornata V3 X Gaming Keyboard. The keys feel very responsive and the different colors are fun to change. I haven’t had any issues playing World of Warcraft Classic – WotLK. We will see how many years I can get out of this one. Hopefully another 12 years!

data.title: Bright and clicky, but adware
data.body: The keyboard is fine if you want a bright and loud keyboard, but customizing the lights with Razor software means accepting adds on your desktop. You can get a similar keyboard from other companies that don't force adds on your screen.

data.title: Letters rub off, become lit up blobs
data.body:
After just a few months of regular use, the black is rubbing off so that I can't see what the letters are. I don't use this keyboard for work. I don't do a lot of typing. Not enough to be considered heavy use. I started using this in February of this year. The black started rubbing off after about 6-8 months-ish. It's been 10 months & now look at it. I'm trying to find stickers for the keys, but many don't look like they'll work well to show the backlight. I use this a lot in a dark environment at night. Razer doesn't sell such things & their customer service isn't going to care.

Otherwise, the keyboard works great as a typical keyboard should, except the program for choosing the lighting scheme is rather finicky.

My last Razer backlit keyboard never had this issue. I'm also having problems with the mouse I got at the same time as this keyboard. Seems like their quality is going down.

data.title: Good!
data.body: It's pretty clicky and soft, arm rest isn't foam, it's hard plastic but doesn't hurt at all really, I think it's magnetic but it's hard to connect....

data.title: refurbished ornata v3
data.body: Bought it refurbished and has been working like its brand new. No missing or sticky keys, all lights work and connects easily with my desktop. Highly recommend the ornata v3.

data.title: Could be better
data.body: The magnets on the wrist rest are extremely weak on my Ornata, received today. Not nearly even strong enough for the keyboard to drag it along for minor adjustments (which I've seen in a video review of the keyboard). If you're moving on from their discontinued Razer Deathstalker, you're probably going to be disappointed, as this isn't a chiclet keyboard, the keys aren't flat, and the wrist rest is completely detached with no way to attach it beyond the magnets (which may be terribly weak like mine). --The left ALT key is smaller and harder to hit, which is noticeable in games that map something you'll regularly use to it. --To be able to customize the colors, you need to install Synapse; hope you like making accounts just to get the most out of your hardware peripheral. If you don't use Synapse, it defaults to a rainbow color flow instead of a single static color, and out-of-the-box it may be brighter than your monitor, too.

data.title: Ornata v3
data.body: Not low profile. Very good bang for your buck keyboard

data.title: Made out of plastic
data.body: Not to good but it does the job

data.title: game keyboard
data.body:
i just got this keyboard there are different hues being shown every few seconds easy to type also it comes with a device to place your palms while touching keys typing is easy
its nice! unlike my last keyboard its also worth noting that the keys are easy to read through the keyboard lights

data.title: I'm enjoying it, but...
data.body: So far I'm really enjoying this keyboard. It is how it's described with the low-profile keys. I found myself performing better (while gaming) almost immediately after replacing my old keyboard with his one. My only issue is that the wrist pad is NOT magnetic, so it's a bit pointless to use as it moves around separately from the keyboard itself. All in all, I would recommend this as a great choice for a cheaper keyboard for gaming or anyone else.

data.title: coating wears off fast
data.body:
i have had this keyboard for just over a year. it isn't used very much. i use my laptop much more. however, in less than a year the coating of the keys is already wearing off, which is disappointing. in the attached picture the "A" and "S" are particularly bad, and the side of keys "E" "D" and "C" are also worn off.

again, i only use this keyboard about an hour or two a day, 4-5 days a week, and often not even that much.

every other aspect of the keyboard has been great, which is why i still list it at a 3 stars.

data.title: Very good for your money
data.body: Been using it for about 2 months so far no issues feels great typing and playing games

data.title: A really great keyboard but with one extremely aggravating issue
data.body: I really enjoyed this keyboard in the short time that I had it. The quality is very pristine, along with the general feel and performance of the keyboard — especially for the fantastic price. However, I was forced to return this keyboard because the Caps-Lock key only has a two key rollover, which means that if more than one key is actively held and then you try to press the Caps-Lock, then it will not register. For most this issue is likely not important, but for me I use Caps-Lock for crouch, so obviously I’m pressing many keys in unison with it; for it to simply not register my input when that is occurring is detrimental. I have no choice but to return it. Dissapointing.

data.title: Happy with Keyboard but not with the shipping
data.body: The keyboard is great and my son is very happy with it. However, I requested it be shipped in Amazon packaging because it was a gift and I wanted it to be a surprise. Instead it arrived without that packaging and was fully visible, so the birthday surprise was ruined.

data.title: Awesome product
data.body: Have been using for a while now and I absolutely love it! Love the wrist rest soo much!

data.title: Amazing, one minor setback
data.body:
I had the original ornata and decided it was time for an upgraded and this V3 delivers on every aspect except for the wrist rest.
The original came with a nice padded wrist rest, while this one is just a solid slab.
Other than that, amazing purchase.

data.title: Good price
data.body: Cant go wrong with a razer that doesn't cost you arms or legs

data.title: Can't register the keyboard & you have to download software to get make lit keyboard all one color.
data.body: The website won't take serial number and/or model number when I try to register my keyboard. Support is hard to find as usual, because these guys don't want to help you. Just sell you their stuff. I'm going to have to download some software to make the keyboard stay one solid color, then probably have to figure out how to make it work with POP_OS. Until then I'm stuck having to dim the keyboard when I play at nite while my wife is sleeping.

data.title: Great for the price
data.body: As an inexpensive gaming keyboard, it works well and with the widows razor utility you can customize the lighting multiple ways. The Linux drivers suck, I have had issues getting it to work on different Linux distributions.

data.title: No Other Color Settings
data.body: It switches colors, goes through a few, but it doesn't work with Razer Synapse. You can't customize the colors being shown on the keyboard. It's comfy, keys sound good (especially for the price). If you need a cheap, comfortable, and LED keyboard this is a decent pic. Just don't expect too much

data.title: Very nice keyboard
data.body: Very nice keyboard. I love the lower profile keys. I always felt like my fingers got hung up in my Huntsman keyboard. This keyboard is still very loud which is why I knocked it down 1 star. Mechanical keyboards sure love that clacky sound.

data.title: Keyboard
data.body: Quality

data.title: Gaming Bliss for my Gamer Kid!
data.body:
The Razer Ornata V3 is a total win for my gaming-obsessed son. The low-profile keys are like a precision dance, making every keystroke feel like a victory. The RGB lighting turns his setup into a party, and the wrist rest is a comfy bonus.

Setting it up was a breeze. My son claims the keyboard adapts to his gaming style, and I'm just thrilled he's happy. If you've got a gamer at home, the Ornata V3 is a game-changer. Two thumbs up from him and a nod of approval from me. Gaming keyboard success!

data.title: What fun
data.body:
My grandson has this keyboard and a mouse from the same folks. I am over 70 yo and these are just fun. Quite bright and quite programmable. Registration is annoying but necessary to get them working with all features.
My wife saw them on my PC and had to have them for hers too.

data.title: Nice keyboard but......
data.body: I brought 2 of these, 1 for me and 1 for my wife. Both of us took a bit to get used to them as the wrist wrest is large, comfortable but large. The keys are also a bit more spaced out than the keyboards we were using so that took a bit of getting used to. Because of this, I find myself hitting the wrong keys sometimes while gaming. My wife loves her keyboard but, in less than 2 months (purchased June 29) her E key is showing ear and the letter is starting to wear off. She works from home and types a lot. But would still expect it to last longer than it has.

data.title: Hard to beat for the price
data.body: Great feeling keyboard and the RGB looks good

data.title: Love it
data.body: Very sturdy
